**Eldrick Tont** "**Tiger** " **Woods** (born December 30, 1975) is an
American [professional golfer](/wiki/Professional_golfer "Professional
golfer") who is among the most successful golfers of all time, and one of the
most popular athletes of the 21st century. He has been one of the [highest-
paid athletes](/wiki/Forbes%27_list_of_the_world%27s_highest-paid_athletes
"Forbes' list of the world's highest-paid athletes") in the world for several
years.[5][6][7] Woods is generally considered one of the greatest golfers of
all time.[8][9][10]

Following an outstanding junior, college, and amateur career, Woods was 20
years old when he turned professional at the end of summer in 1996. By the end
of April 1997, he had won three [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA Tour") events
in addition to his first major, the [1997
Masters](/wiki/1997_Masters_Tournament "1997 Masters Tournament"). Woods won
this tournament by 12 strokes in a record-breaking performance and earned
$486,000. He first reached the [number one
position](/wiki/List_of_World_Number_One_male_golfers "List of World Number
One male golfers") in the [world rankings](/wiki/Official_World_Golf_Ranking
"Official World Golf Ranking") in June 1997, less than a year after turning
pro. Throughout the 2000s, Woods was the dominant force in golf—he won the
[2000 U.S. Open](/wiki/2000_U.S._Open_\(golf\) "2000 U.S. Open \(golf\)") by a
record 15-shot margin. He was the top-ranked golfer in the world from August
1999 to September 2004 (264 weeks) and again from June 2005 to October 2010
(281 weeks).

Woods took a self-imposed hiatus from professional golf from December 2009 to
early April 2010 to resolve marital issues. Woods and his estranged wife
[Elin](/wiki/Elin_Nordegren "Elin Nordegren") eventually divorced. His many
alleged extramarital indiscretions were revealed by several women, through
many worldwide media sources.[11] This coincided with a series of injuries,
treatments by the controversial doctor Anthony Galea, who had been linked to
HGH,[12] and a loss of golf form. His placement in the Official World Golf
Rankings gradually fell to a low of No. 58 in November 2011.[13][14] He ended
a career-high winless streak of 107 weeks when he triumphed in the [Chevron
World Challenge](/wiki/Chevron_World_Challenge "Chevron World Challenge") in
December 2011.[14] After winning the [Arnold Palmer
Invitational](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer_Invitational "Arnold Palmer Invitational")
on March 25, 2013, he ascended to the No.1 ranking once again, holding the top
spot until May 2014, by which time he had been ranked number one for a record
total of 683 weeks. From 2014–2017, Woods had been unable to recapture his
dominant form, undergoing four [back surgeries](/wiki/Discectomy "Discectomy")
in 2014, 2015 and 2017.[15] In May 2016, Woods dropped out of the world top
500 for the first time in his professional career.[16] After falling to #1199
in the World Golf Ranking in December 2017, Woods rose over 1000 places by
mid-2018.[17][18] In September 2018, he won his first tournament in five years
with a victory at the [Tour Championship](/wiki/Tour_Championship "Tour
Championship") and moved to #13 in the [Official World Golf
Rankings](/wiki/Official_World_Golf_Rankings "Official World Golf Rankings").

Woods has broken numerous golf records. He has been World Number One for the
most consecutive weeks and for the greatest total number of weeks of any
golfer. He has been awarded [PGA Player of the
Year](/wiki/PGA_Player_of_the_Year "PGA Player of the Year") a record eleven
times,[19] the [Byron Nelson Award](/wiki/Vardon_Trophy "Vardon Trophy") for
lowest adjusted scoring average a record eight times, and has the record of
leading the [money list](/wiki/PGA_Tour#Money_winners_and_most_wins_leaders
"PGA Tour") in ten different seasons. He has won 14 professional [major golf
championships](/wiki/Men%27s_major_golf_championships "Men's major golf
championships"), where he trails only [Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus
"Jack Nicklaus") who leads with 18, and 80 [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA
Tour") events, second all-time behind [Sam Snead](/wiki/Sam_Snead "Sam Snead")
(82).[20] Woods leads all active golfers in [career major
wins](/wiki/List_of_men%27s_major_championships_winning_golfers "List of men's
major championships winning golfers") and [career PGA Tour
wins](/wiki/List_of_golfers_with_most_PGA_Tour_wins "List of golfers with most
PGA Tour wins"). He is the youngest player to achieve the career [Grand
Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(golf\) "Grand Slam \(golf\)"), and the youngest and
fastest to win 50 tournaments on tour. Additionally, Woods is only the second
golfer (after Nicklaus) to have achieved a career Grand Slam three times.
Woods has won 18 [World Golf Championships](/wiki/World_Golf_Championships
"World Golf Championships"), and won at least one of those events in each of
the first 11 years after they began in 1999. Woods and [Rory
McIlroy](/wiki/Rory_McIlroy "Rory McIlroy") are the only golfers to win both
[The Silver Medal](/wiki/The_Open_Championship#Silver_Medal_winners "The Open
Championship") and The Gold Medal at The Open Championship.

## Background and family

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Tiger_and_Earl_Woods_Fort_Bragg_2004.jpg/220px-
Tiger_and_Earl_Woods_Fort_Bragg_2004.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_and_Earl_Woods_Fort_Bragg_2004.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_and_Earl_Woods_Fort_Bragg_2004.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods and his father [Earl](/wiki/Earl_Woods "Earl Woods") at [Fort
Bragg](/wiki/Fort_Bragg "Fort Bragg"), [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina
"North Carolina") in 2004

Woods was born in 1975 in [Cypress, California](/wiki/Cypress,_California
"Cypress, California"),[21] to [Earl](/wiki/Earl_Woods "Earl Woods")[22] and
Kultida "Tida" Woods.[23] He is the only child of their marriage, and has two
half-brothers, Earl Jr. and Kevin, as well as a half-sister named Royce from
his father's first marriage.[24]

Kultida (née Punsawad) is originally from [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand
"Thailand"), where Earl had met her on a tour of duty in 1968. She is of mixed
[Thai](/wiki/Thai_people "Thai people"), [Chinese](/wiki/Han_Chinese "Han
Chinese"), and [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") ancestry.[25] Earl
was a retired [lieutenant colonel](/wiki/Lieutenant_colonel "Lieutenant
colonel") and [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War") veteran who was
mostly [African American](/wiki/African_American "African American") with
traces of European descent. Earl's mother Maude Carter was light skinned. Some
people suggested that she had [Native
American](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas") and Chinese ancestry.[26] Tiger refers to his ethnic make-up as
_"[Cablinasian](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Cablinasian
"wikt:Cablinasian")"_ (a [syllabic abbreviation](/wiki/Syllabic_abbreviation
"Syllabic abbreviation") he coined from [**Ca** ucasian](/wiki/Caucasian_race
"Caucasian race"), [**Bl** ack](/wiki/Black_people "Black people"), [American
**In** dian](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in
the United States"), and **[Asian](/wiki/Asian_people "Asian people")**).[27]

Woods' first name—Eldrick—was coined by his mother because it began with "E"
(for Earl) and ended with "K" (for Kultida). His middle name Tont is a
traditional Thai name. He was nicknamed Tiger in honor of his father's friend
Col. Vuong Dang Phong, who had also been known as Tiger.[28]

Woods' niece, [Cheyenne Woods](/wiki/Cheyenne_Woods "Cheyenne Woods"), played
for the [Wake Forest University](/wiki/Wake_Forest_Demon_Deacons "Wake Forest
Demon Deacons") golf team and turned professional in 2012, when she made her
pro debut in the [LPGA Championship](/wiki/LPGA_Championship "LPGA
Championship").[29]

## Early life and amateur golf career

Woods grew up in [Orange County](/wiki/Orange_County,_California "Orange
County, California"), California. He was a child prodigy who was introduced to
golf before the age of two by his athletic father, Earl Woods. Earl was a
single-digit handicap amateur golfer who also was one of the earliest African-
American college [baseball](/wiki/Baseball "Baseball") players at [Kansas
State University](/wiki/Kansas_State_University "Kansas State
University").[30] Tiger's father was a member of the military and had playing
privileges at the Navy golf course beside the [Joint Forces Training
Base](/wiki/Joint_Forces_Training_Base_-_Los_Alamitos "Joint Forces Training
Base - Los Alamitos") in [Los Alamitos](/wiki/Los_Alamitos,_California "Los
Alamitos, California"), which allowed Tiger to play there. Tiger also played
at the par 3 Heartwell golf course in [Long
Beach](/wiki/Long_Beach,_California "Long Beach, California"), as well as some
of the [municipals](/wiki/Golf_course#Municipal "Golf course") in Long
Beach.[31]

In 1978, Tiger putted against comedian [Bob Hope](/wiki/Bob_Hope "Bob Hope")
in a television appearance on _[The Mike Douglas
Show](/wiki/The_Mike_Douglas_Show "The Mike Douglas Show")_. At age three, he
shot a 48 over nine holes at the Navy course. At age five, he appeared in
_[Golf Digest](/wiki/Golf_Digest "Golf Digest")_ and on
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")'s
_[That's Incredible!](/wiki/That%27s_Incredible! "That's Incredible!")_[32]
Before turning seven, Tiger won the Under Age 10 section of the Drive, Pitch,
and Putt competition, held at the Navy Golf Course in Cypress, California.[33]
In 1984 at the age of eight, he won the 9–10 boys' event, the youngest age
group available, at the [Junior World Golf
Championships](/wiki/Junior_World_Golf_Championships "Junior World Golf
Championships").[34] He first broke 80 at age eight.[35] He went on to win the
Junior World Championships six times, including four consecutive wins from
1988 to 1991.[36][37][38][39][40]

Woods' father Earl wrote that Tiger first defeated him at the age of 11 years,
with Earl trying his best. Earl lost to Tiger every time from then on.[41][42]
Woods first broke 70 on a regulation golf course at age 12.[43]

When Woods was 13 years old, he played in the 1989 Big I, which was his first
major national junior tournament. In the final round, he was paired with pro
[John Daly](/wiki/John_Daly_\(golfer\) "John Daly \(golfer\)"), who was then
relatively unknown. The event's format placed a professional with each group
of juniors who had qualified. Daly birdied three of the last four holes to
beat Woods by only one stroke.[44] As a young teenager, Woods first met [Jack
Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus") in Los Angeles at the [Bel-Air
Country Club](/wiki/Bel-Air_Country_Club "Bel-Air Country Club"), when
Nicklaus was performing a clinic for the club's members. Woods was part of the
show, and he impressed Nicklaus and the crowd with his skills and
potential.[45] Earl Woods had researched in detail the career accomplishments
of Nicklaus and had set his young son the goals of breaking those records.[43]

Woods was 15-years-old and a student at [Western High
School](/wiki/Western_High_School_\(Anaheim,_California\) "Western High School
\(Anaheim, California\)") in Anaheim when he became the youngest [U.S. Junior
Amateur](/wiki/U.S._Junior_Amateur "U.S. Junior Amateur") champion; this was a
record that stood until it was broken by Jim Liu in 2010.[46] He was named
1991's [Southern California Amateur Player of the
Year](/w/index.php?title=Southern_California_Amateur_Player_of_the_Year&action=edit&redlink=1
"Southern California Amateur Player of the Year \(page does not exist\)") (for
the second consecutive year) and Golf Digest Junior Amateur Player of the
Year. In 1992, he defended his title at the U.S. Junior Amateur Championship,
becoming the tournament's first two-time winner. He also competed in his first
PGA Tour event, the [Nissan Los Angeles Open](/wiki/Nissan_Los_Angeles_Open
"Nissan Los Angeles Open") (he missed the 36-hole cut), and was named Golf
Digest Amateur Player of the Year, Golf World Player of the Year, and Golfweek
National Amateur of the Year.[47][48]

The following year, Woods won his third consecutive U.S. Junior Amateur
Championship; he remains the event's only three-time winner.[49] In 1994, at
the [TPC at Sawgrass](/wiki/TPC_at_Sawgrass "TPC at Sawgrass") in Florida, he
became the youngest winner of the [U.S. Amateur
Championship](/wiki/United_States_Amateur_Championship_\(golf\) "United States
Amateur Championship \(golf\)"), a record he held until 2008 when it was
broken by [Danny Lee](/wiki/Danny_Lee_\(golfer\) "Danny Lee \(golfer\)").[50]
He was a member of the American team at the 1994 [Eisenhower
Trophy](/wiki/Eisenhower_Trophy "Eisenhower Trophy") [World Amateur Golf Team
Championships](/wiki/World_Amateur_Golf_Team_Championships "World Amateur Golf
Team Championships") (winning), and the 1995 [Walker Cup](/wiki/Walker_Cup
"Walker Cup") (losing).[51][52]

Woods graduated from Western High School at age 18 in 1994 and was voted "Most
Likely to Succeed" among the graduating class. He had starred for the high
school's golf team under coach Don Crosby.[53]

Woods overcame difficulties with [stuttering](/wiki/Stuttering "Stuttering")
as a boy.[54][55][56] This was not known until he wrote a letter to a boy who
contemplated suicide. Woods wrote, "I know what it's like to be different and
to sometimes not fit in. I also stuttered as a child and I would talk to my
dog and he would sit there and listen until he fell asleep. I also took a
class for two years to help me, and I finally learned to stop."[57]

## College golf career

Woods was heavily recruited by college golf powers. He chose [Stanford
University](/wiki/Stanford_Cardinal "Stanford Cardinal"), the 1994
[NCAA](/wiki/NCAA "NCAA") champions. He enrolled at Stanford in the fall of
1994 under a golf scholarship and won his first collegiate event, the 40th
Annual William H. Tucker Invitational, that September.[58] He selected a major
in economics and was nicknamed "[Urkel](/wiki/Steve_Urkel "Steve Urkel")" by
college teammate [Notah Begay III](/wiki/Notah_Begay_III "Notah Begay
III").[59] In 1995, he successfully defended his U.S. Amateur title at the
[Newport Country Club](/wiki/Newport_Country_Club "Newport Country Club") in
[Rhode Island](/wiki/Rhode_Island "Rhode Island")[50] and was voted Pac-10
Player of the Year, NCAA First Team All-American, and Stanford's Male Freshman
of the Year (an award that encompasses all sports).[60][61]

At age 19 (two years before he won the tournament), Woods participated in his
first PGA Tour major, the [1995 Masters](/wiki/1995_Masters_Tournament "1995
Masters Tournament"), and tied for 41st as the only amateur to make the cut.
At age 20 in 1996, he became the first golfer to win three consecutive U.S.
Amateur titles[62] and won the [NCAA individual golf
championship](/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_Men%27s_Golf_Championships "NCAA Division
I Men's Golf Championships").[63] In winning the silver medal as leading
amateur at [The Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open
Championship"), he tied the record for an amateur aggregate score of 281.[64]
He left college after two years in order to turn professional in the golf
industry. In 1996, Woods moved out of California, stating in 2013 that it was
due to the state's high tax rate.[65][66]

## Professional career

Main article: [Professional golf career of Tiger
Woods](/wiki/Professional_golf_career_of_Tiger_Woods "Professional golf career
of Tiger Woods")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Tiger_Woods_2005.jpg/170px-
Tiger_Woods_2005.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_2005.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_2005.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods in 2001

Woods turned [pro](/wiki/Professional_golfer "Professional golfer") at age 20
in August 1996 and immediately signed advertising deals with [Nike,
Inc.](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc.") and [Titleist](/wiki/Titleist "Titleist")
that ranked as the most lucrative endorsement contracts in golf history at
that time.[67][68] Woods was named _[Sports
Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated")_ 's 1996
[Sportsman of the Year](/wiki/Sportsman_of_the_Year "Sportsman of the Year")
and [PGA Tour Rookie of the Year](/wiki/PGA_Tour_Rookie_of_the_Year "PGA Tour
Rookie of the Year").[69] On April 13, 1997, he won his first
[major](/wiki/Men%27s_major_golf_championships "Men's major golf
championships"), [the Masters](/wiki/1997_Masters_Tournament "1997 Masters
Tournament"), in record-breaking fashion and became the tournament's youngest
winner at age 21.[70] Two months later, he set the record for the fastest
ascent to No. 1 in the [Official World Golf
Rankings](/wiki/Official_World_Golf_Rankings "Official World Golf
Rankings").[71] After a lackluster 1998, Woods finished the 1999 season with
eight wins, including the [PGA Championship](/wiki/1999_PGA_Championship "1999
PGA Championship"), a feat not achieved since 1974.[72][73]

In 2000, Woods won six consecutive events on the PGA Tour, which was the
longest winning streak since [Ben Hogan](/wiki/Ben_Hogan "Ben Hogan") did it
in 1948. One of these was the [2000 U.S. Open](/wiki/2000_U.S._Open_\(golf\)
"2000 U.S. Open \(golf\)"), where he broke or tied nine tournament records in
what _Sports Illustrated_ called "the greatest performance in golf history",
in which Woods won the tournament by a record 15-stroke margin and earned a
check for $800,000.[74] At age 24, he became the youngest golfer to achieve
the Career [Grand Slam](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(golf\) "Grand Slam \(golf\)").[75]
At the end of 2000, Woods had won nine of the twenty PGA Tour events he
entered and had broken the record for lowest scoring average in tour history.
He was named the _Sports Illustrated_ Sportsman of the Year, the only athlete
to be honored twice, and was ranked by Golf Digest magazine as the twelfth-
best golfer of all time.[76][77]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a3/TigerWoods2004RyderCup1.jpg/170px-
TigerWoods2004RyderCup1.jpg)](/wiki/File:TigerWoods2004RyderCup1.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TigerWoods2004RyderCup1.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods at the [2004 Ryder Cup](/wiki/2004_Ryder_Cup "2004 Ryder Cup")

When Woods won the [2001 Masters](/wiki/2001_Masters_Tournament "2001 Masters
Tournament"), he became the only player to win four consecutive major
professional golf titles, although not in the same calendar year.[78]
Following a stellar 2001 and 2002 in which Woods continued to dominate the
tour, Woods' career hit a slump.[72][79] He did not win a major in 2003 or
2004. In September 2004, [Vijay Singh](/wiki/Vijay_Singh "Vijay Singh")
overtook Woods in the Official World Golf Rankings, ending Woods' record
streak of 264 weeks at #1.[80]

Woods rebounded in 2005, winning six official PGA Tour money events and
reclaiming the top spot in July after swapping it back and forth with Singh
over the first half of the year.[81]

Woods began dominantly in 2006, winning his first two PGA tournaments but
failing to capture his fifth Masters championship in April.[82][83] Following
the death of his father in May, Woods took a nine-week hiatus from the tour
and appeared rusty upon his return at the U.S. Open at [Winged
Foot](/wiki/Winged_Foot "Winged Foot"), where he missed the cut.[84] However,
he quickly returned to form and ended the year by winning six consecutive tour
events. At the season's close, Woods had 54 total wins that included 12
majors; he had broken the tour records for both total wins and total majors
wins over eleven seasons.[85]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Tiger_Woods_Masters_2006.jpg/220px-
Tiger_Woods_Masters_2006.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_Masters_2006.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_Masters_2006.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods at the [2006 Masters](/wiki/2006_Masters_Tournament "2006 Masters
Tournament")

Woods continued to excel in 2007 and the first part of 2008. In April 2008, he
underwent knee surgery and missed the next two months on the tour.[86] Woods
returned for the [2008 U.S. Open](/wiki/2008_U.S._Open_\(golf\) "2008 U.S.
Open \(golf\)"), where he struggled the first day but ultimately claimed a
dramatic sudden death victory over [Rocco Mediate](/wiki/Rocco_Mediate "Rocco
Mediate") that followed an 18-hole playoff, after which Mediate said, "This
guy does things that are just not normal by any stretch of the imagination,"
and Kenny Perry added, "He beat everybody on one leg."[87][88][89] Two days
later, Woods announced that he would miss the remainder of the season due to
additional knee surgery, and that his knee was more severely damaged than
previously revealed, prompting even greater praise for his U.S. Open
performance. Woods called it "my greatest ever championship."[90][91][92] In
Woods' absence, TV ratings for the remainder of the season suffered a huge
decline from 2007.[93]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Tiger_Woods_-
_AT%26T_National_tournament_2009.jpg/170px-Tiger_Woods_-
_AT%26T_National_tournament_2009.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_-
_AT%26T_National_tournament_2009.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_-_AT%26T_National_tournament_2009.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods competing at the third annual Earl Woods Memorial Pro-Am (July 1, 2009)

Woods had a much anticipated return to golf in 2009, when he performed well.
His comeback included a spectacular performance at the [2009 Presidents
Cup](/wiki/2009_Presidents_Cup "2009 Presidents Cup"), but he failed to win a
major, the first year since 2004 that he had not done so.[94][95][96] After
his marital infidelities came to light and received massive media coverage at
the end of 2009 (see further details below), Woods announced in December that
he would be taking an indefinite break from competitive golf.[11] In February
2010, he delivered a televised apology for his behavior, saying "I was wrong
and I was foolish."[97] During this period, several companies ended their
endorsement deals with Woods.[98]

Woods returned to competition in April at the [2010
Masters](/wiki/2010_Masters_Tournament "2010 Masters Tournament"), where he
finished tied for fourth place.[99] He followed the Masters with poor showings
at the Quail Hollow Championship and the Players Championship, where he
withdrew in the fourth round, citing injury.[100] Shortly afterward, [Hank
Haney](/wiki/Hank_Haney "Hank Haney"), Woods' coach since 2003, resigned the
position. In August, Woods hired [Sean
Foley](/wiki/Sean_Foley_\(golf_instructor\) "Sean Foley \(golf instructor\)")
as Haney's replacement. The rest of the season went badly for Woods, who
failed to win a single event for the first time since turning professional,
while nevertheless finishing the season ranked No. 2 in the world.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/TigerWoodsOct2011.jpg/220px-
TigerWoodsOct2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:TigerWoodsOct2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TigerWoodsOct2011.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods at a [Chevron World Challenge](/wiki/Chevron_World_Challenge "Chevron
World Challenge") charity event (2011)

In 2011, Woods' performance continued to suffer; this took its toll on his
ranking. After falling to No. 7 in March, he rebounded to No. 5 with a strong
showing at the [2011 Masters Tournament](/wiki/2011_Masters_Tournament "2011
Masters Tournament"), where he tied for fourth place.[101][102][103] Due to
leg injuries incurred at the Masters, he missed several summer stops on the
PGA Tour. In July, he fired his longtime caddy [Steve
Williams](/wiki/Steve_Williams_\(caddy\) "Steve Williams \(caddy\)") (who was
shocked by the dismissal), and replaced him on an interim basis with friend
Bryon Bell.[104][105] After returning to tournament play in August, Woods
continued to falter, and his ranking gradually fell to a low of #58.[14] He
rose to No. 50 in mid-November after a third-place finish at the [Emirates
Australian Open](/wiki/Emirates_Australian_Open "Emirates Australian Open"),
and broke his winless streak with a victory at December's [Chevron World
Challenge](/wiki/Chevron_World_Challenge "Chevron World Challenge").[14][106]

Woods began his 2012 season with two tournaments (the [Abu Dhabi HSBC Golf
Championship](/wiki/Abu_Dhabi_HSBC_Golf_Championship "Abu Dhabi HSBC Golf
Championship") and the [AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-
Am](/wiki/AT%26T_Pebble_Beach_National_Pro-Am "AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-
Am")) where he started off well, but struggled on the final rounds. Following
the [WGC-Accenture Match Play Championship](/wiki/WGC-
Accenture_Match_Play_Championship "WGC-Accenture Match Play Championship"),
where he was knocked out in the second round by missing a 5-foot putt,[107]
Woods revised his putting technique and tied for second at the [Honda
Classic](/wiki/Honda_Classic "Honda Classic"), with the lowest final round
score in his PGA Tour career. After a short time off due to another leg
injury, Woods won the [Arnold Palmer
Invitational](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer_Invitational "Arnold Palmer Invitational"),
his first win on the PGA Tour since the [BMW
Championship](/wiki/BMW_Championship_\(PGA_Tour\) "BMW Championship \(PGA
Tour\)") in September 2009. Following several dismal performances, Woods
notched his 73rd PGA Tour win at the [Memorial
Tournament](/wiki/Memorial_Tournament "Memorial Tournament") in June, tying
[Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus") in second place for most
PGA Tour victories;[108] a month later, Woods surpassed Nicklaus with a win at
the [AT&T National](/wiki/AT%26T_National "AT&T National"), to trail only [Sam
Snead](/wiki/Sam_Snead "Sam Snead"), who accumulated 82 PGA tour wins.[109]

The year 2013 would bring a return of Woods' dominating play. In January, he
won the [Farmers Insurance Open](/wiki/Farmers_Insurance_Open "Farmers
Insurance Open") by four shots for his 75th PGA Tour win. It was the seventh
time he had won the event.[110] In March, he won the [WGC-Cadillac
Championship](/wiki/WGC-Cadillac_Championship "WGC-Cadillac Championship"),
also for the seventh time, giving him his 17th WGC title and first since
2009.[111] Two weeks later, he won the [Arnold Palmer
Invitational](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer_Invitational "Arnold Palmer Invitational"),
winning the event for a record-tying 8th time. The win moved him back to the
top of the world rankings.[112] To commemorate that achievement, Nike was
quick to launch an ad with the tagline "winning takes care of
everything".[113]

During the [2013 Masters](/wiki/2013_Masters_Tournament "2013 Masters
Tournament"), Woods faced disqualification after unwittingly admitting in a
post-round interview with [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") that he had taken an
illegal drop on the par-5 15th hole when his third shot had bounced off the
pin and into the water. After further [review of television
footage](/wiki/Trial_by_television_in_golf_tournaments "Trial by television in
golf tournaments"), Woods was assessed a two-stroke penalty for the drop but
was not disqualified.[114] He finished tied for fourth in the event. Woods won
[The Players Championship](/wiki/The_Players_Championship "The Players
Championship") in May 2013, his second career win at the event, notching his
fourth win of the 2013 season. It was the quickest he had gotten to four wins
in any season in his professional career.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Tiger_Woods_2014.jpg/220px-
Tiger_Woods_2014.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_2014.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_2014.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods practicing before the 2014 [Quicken Loans
National](/wiki/Quicken_Loans_National "Quicken Loans National")

Woods had a poor showing at the [2013 U.S Open](/wiki/2013_U.S._Open_\(golf\)
"2013 U.S. Open \(golf\)") as a result of an elbow injury sustained at [The
Players Championship](/wiki/The_Players_Championship "The Players
Championship"). In finishing at 13-over-par, he recorded his worst score as a
professional and finished 12 strokes behind winner [Justin
Rose](/wiki/Justin_Rose "Justin Rose"). After a prolonged break because of the
injury, during which he missed the [Greenbrier
Classic](/wiki/Greenbrier_Classic "Greenbrier Classic") and his own [AT&T
National](/wiki/AT%26T_National "AT&T National"), he returned at the [Open
Championship](/wiki/2013_Open_Championship "2013 Open Championship") at
[Muirfield](/wiki/Muirfield "Muirfield"). Despite being in contention all week
and beginning the final round only two strokes behind [Lee
Westwood](/wiki/Lee_Westwood "Lee Westwood"), he struggled with the speed of
the greens and could only manage a 3-over-par 74 that left him tied for 6th
place, five strokes behind eventual winner [Phil
Mickelson](/wiki/Phil_Mickelson "Phil Mickelson"). Two weeks later, Woods
returned to form at the [WGC-Bridgestone Invitational](/wiki/2013_WGC-
Bridgestone_Invitational "2013 WGC-Bridgestone Invitational"), recording his
5th win of the season and 8th win at the event in its 15-year history. His
second round 61 matched his record score on the PGA Tour and could easily have
been a 59 were it not for some short missed birdie putts on the closing holes.
This gave him a seven stroke lead that he held onto for the rest of the
tournament. Woods would never contend at the PGA Championship at Oak Hill
Country Club and would come short of winning a major for the 5th full season,
only contending in two of the four majors in 2013.

After a slow start to 2014, Woods injured himself during the final round of
the [Honda Classic](/wiki/Honda_Classic "Honda Classic") and was unable to
finish the tournament. He withdrew after the 13th hole, citing back pain.[115]
He subsequently competed in the [WGC-Cadillac Championship](/wiki/WGC-
Cadillac_Championship "WGC-Cadillac Championship") but was visibly in pain
during much of the last round. He was forced to skip the [Arnold Palmer
Invitational](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer_Invitational "Arnold Palmer Invitational")
at the end of March 2014,[116] and after undergoing [back
surgery](/wiki/Microdiscectomy "Microdiscectomy"), he announced on April 1
that he would miss the [Masters](/wiki/Masters_Tournament "Masters
Tournament") for the first time since 1994.[117] Woods returned at the
[Quicken Loans National](/wiki/Quicken_Loans_National "Quicken Loans
National") in June, however he stated that his expectations for the week were
low. He would struggle with nearly every aspect of his game and miss the cut.
He next played at [The Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The
Open Championship"), contested at Hoylake, where Woods had won eight years
prior. Woods fired a brilliant 69 in the first round to put himself in
contention, but shot 77 on Friday and would eventually finish 69th. Despite
his back pain, he played at the [2014 PGA
Championship](/wiki/2014_PGA_Championship "2014 PGA Championship") where he
failed to make the cut. On August 25, 2014, Woods and his swing coach Sean
Foley parted ways. In the four years under Foley, he won eight times but no
majors. He had previously won eight majors with Harmon and six with Haney.
Woods said there is currently no timetable to find a replacement swing
coach.[118]

On February 5, 2015, Woods withdrew from the [Farmers Insurance
Open](/wiki/Farmers_Insurance_Open "Farmers Insurance Open") after another
back injury.[119] Woods stated on his website that it was unrelated to his
previous surgery and he would take a break from golf until his back
healed.[120] He returned for the [Masters](/wiki/2015_Masters_Tournament "2015
Masters Tournament"), finishing in a tie for 17th. In the final round, Woods
injured his wrist after his club hit a tree root. He later stated that a bone
popped out of his wrist, but he adjusted it back into place and finished the
round.[121] Woods then missed the cut at the 2015 [U.S.
Open](/wiki/2015_U.S._Open_\(golf\) "2015 U.S. Open \(golf\)") and [Open
Championship](/wiki/2015_Open_Championship "2015 Open Championship"), the
first time Woods missed the cut at consecutive majors, finishing near the
bottom of the leaderboard both times.[122][123] He finished tied for 18th at
the [Quicken Loans National](/wiki/Quicken_Loans_National "Quicken Loans
National") on August 2.[124] In late August 2015, Woods played quite well at
the Wyndham Championship finishing the tournament at 13-under, only four
strokes behind the winner, and tied for 10th place.[125] Woods offered only a
brief comment on the speculation that he was still recovering from [back
surgery](/wiki/Microdiscectomy "Microdiscectomy"), saying it was "just my hip"
but offering no specifics.[126]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Tiger_Woods_2018_US_Open_26.jpg/180px-
Tiger_Woods_2018_US_Open_26.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_2018_US_Open_26.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_2018_US_Open_26.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods at the [2018 U.S. Open](/wiki/2018_U.S._Open_\(golf\) "2018 U.S. Open
\(golf\)")

Woods had back surgery on September 16, 2015. In late March 2016, he announced
that he would miss the [Masters](/wiki/Masters_Tournament "Masters
Tournament") while he recovered from the surgery;[127] he had also missed the
2014 Masters due to a back problem.[128] "I'm absolutely making progress, and
I'm really happy with how far I've come," he explained in a statement. "But I
still have no timetable to return to competitive golf."[129] However, he did
attend the Masters Champions Dinner on April 5, 2016.[130] For the first time
in his career, he missed all four majors in one year due to problems with his
back. In October 2016, he told Charlie Rose on PBS that he still wanted to
break Jack Nicklaus's record of 18 major titles.[131] Woods underwent back
surgery in December 2016 and spent the next 15 months off the Tour. He made
his return to competitive golf in the [Hero World
Challenge](/wiki/Hero_World_Challenge "Hero World Challenge").[132]

Woods' back problems continued to hinder him in 2017, as he missed the cut at
the [Farmers Insurance Open](/wiki/Farmers_Insurance_Open "Farmers Insurance
Open") in January, and pulled out of a European Tour event in
[Dubai](/wiki/Dubai "Dubai") on February 3. On March 31, Woods announced on
his website that he would not be playing in the [2017 Masters
Tournament](/wiki/2017_Masters_Tournament "2017 Masters Tournament") despite
being cleared to play by his doctors. Woods said that although he was happy
with his rehabilitation, he did not feel "tournament ready."[133][134] On
April 20, Woods announced that he had undergone his fourth back surgery since
2014 to alleviate back and leg pain. Recovery time required up to six months,
meaning that Woods would spend the rest of the year without playing any
professional golf.[135][136] Woods returned to competitive golf at the Hero
World Challenge in the Bahamas. He shot rounds of 69-68-75-68 and finished
tied for 9th place. His world ranking went from 1,199th to 668th, which was
the biggest jump in the world rankings in his career.

On Sunday, March 11, 2018, he finished one-shot back and tied for second at
the Valspar Championship in Florida, his first top-five finish on the PGA Tour
since 2013.[137] He then tied for sixth with a score of five under par at the
[2018 Open Championship](/wiki/2018_Open_Championship "2018 Open
Championship").[138] At the last major of the year Woods finished second at
the [2018 PGA Championship](/wiki/2018_PGA_Championship "2018 PGA
Championship"), two shots behind the winner [Brooks
Koepka](/wiki/Brooks_Koepka "Brooks Koepka"). It was his best result in a
major since 2009 (second at the [2009 PGA
Championship](/wiki/2009_PGA_Championship "2009 PGA Championship")) and moved
up to 26th in the world rankings. His final round of 64 was his best ever
final round in a major.[139][18]

Woods got back in the winner's circle for the 80th time in his PGA Tour career
on September 23, 2018, when he won the season-ending [Tour
Championship](/wiki/Tour_Championship "Tour Championship") at East Lake Golf
Club for the second time, and that tournament for the third time. He shot
rounds of 65-68-65-71 to win by two strokes over [Billy
Horschel](/wiki/Billy_Horschel "Billy Horschel"). He nearly also won the FedEx
Cup, but [Justin Rose](/wiki/Justin_Rose "Justin Rose") made a birdie on the
18th hole to win by 41 points over Woods.[140]

### Honors

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Tiger_Woods_drives_by_Allison.jpg/220px-
Tiger_Woods_drives_by_Allison.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_drives_by_Allison.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_drives_by_Allison.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods checking his drive in 2007

On August 20, 2007, California Governor [Arnold
Schwarzenegger](/wiki/Arnold_Schwarzenegger "Arnold Schwarzenegger") and his
wife [Maria Shriver](/wiki/Maria_Shriver "Maria Shriver") announced that Woods
would be inducted into the [California Hall of
Fame](/wiki/California_Hall_of_Fame "California Hall of Fame"). He was
inducted December 5, 2007 at [The California Museum for History, Women and the
Arts](/wiki/The_California_Museum_for_History,_Women_and_the_Arts "The
California Museum for History, Women and the Arts") in Sacramento.[141][142]

In December 2009, Woods was named "Athlete of the Decade" by the Associated
Press.[143] He was named [Associated Press Male Athlete of the
Year](/wiki/Associated_Press_Male_Athlete_of_the_Year "Associated Press Male
Athlete of the Year")[144] a record-tying four times, and is one of only two
people to be named _[Sports Illustrated](/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports
Illustrated")_ 's [Sportsman of the Year](/wiki/Sportsman_of_the_Year
"Sportsman of the Year") more than once.

Since his record-breaking win at the [1997
Masters](/wiki/1997_Masters_Tournament "1997 Masters Tournament"), Woods
became the biggest name in golf, and his presence in tournaments drew a huge
fan following . Some sources have credited him for dramatically increasing
prize money in golf, generating interest in new PGA tournament audiences, and
for drawing the largest TV ratings in golf
history.[69][145][146][147][148][149]

### Endorsements

During the first decade of his professional career, Woods was the world's most
marketable athlete.[150] Shortly after his 21st birthday in 1996, he signed
endorsement deals with numerous companies, including [General
Motors](/wiki/General_Motors "General Motors"), [Titleist](/wiki/Titleist
"Titleist"), [General Mills](/wiki/General_Mills "General Mills"), [American
Express](/wiki/American_Express "American Express"),
[Accenture](/wiki/Accenture "Accenture"), and [Nike, Inc.](/wiki/Nike,_Inc.
"Nike, Inc.") In 2000, he signed a 5-year, $105 million contract extension
with Nike, which was the largest endorsement package signed by a professional
athlete at that time.[151] Woods' endorsement has been credited with playing a
significant role in taking the Nike Golf brand from a "start-up" golf company
earlier in the previous decade to becoming the leading golf apparel company in
the world and a major player in the equipment and golf ball market.[150][152]
Nike Golf is one of the fastest growing brands in the sport, with an estimated
$600 million in sales.[153] Woods has been described as the "ultimate
endorser" for Nike Golf,[153] frequently seen wearing Nike gear during
tournaments, and even in advertisements for other products.[151] Woods
receives a percentage from the sales of Nike Golf apparel, footwear, golf
equipment, golf balls,[150] and has a building named after him at Nike's
headquarters campus in [Beaverton](/wiki/Beaverton,_Oregon "Beaverton,
Oregon"), Oregon.[154]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/US_Navy_040303-N-5319A-001_Tiger_Woods_meets_Commander_Carrier_Group_Eight_%28CCG-8%29_Rear_Adm._Denby_H._Starling_II%2C_on_the_flag_bridge_aboard_the_aircraft_carrier_USS_George_Washington_%28CVN_73%29.jpg/220px-
thumbnail.jpg)](/wiki/File:US_Navy_040303-N-5319A-001_Tiger_Woods_meets_Commander_Carrier_Group_Eight_\(CCG-8\)_Rear_Adm._Denby_H._Starling_II,_on_the_flag_bridge_aboard_the_aircraft_carrier_USS_George_Washington_\(CVN_73\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:US_Navy_040303-N-5319A-001_Tiger_Woods_meets_Commander_Carrier_Group_Eight_\(CCG-8\)_Rear_Adm._Denby_H._Starling_II,_on_the_flag_bridge_aboard_the_aircraft_carrier_USS_George_Washington_\(CVN_73\).jpg
"Enlarge")

Woods visiting aircraft carrier [USS  _George Washington_
(CVN-73)](/wiki/USS_George_Washington_\(CVN-73\) "USS George Washington
\(CVN-73\)") in the [Persian Gulf](/wiki/Persian_Gulf "Persian Gulf") before
participating in the 2004 [Dubai Desert Classic](/wiki/Dubai_Desert_Classic
"Dubai Desert Classic")

In 2002, Woods was involved in every aspect of the launch of
[Buick](/wiki/Buick "Buick")'s [Rendezvous](/wiki/Buick_Rendezvous "Buick
Rendezvous") [SUV](/wiki/SUV "SUV"). A company spokesman stated that Buick was
happy with the value of Woods' endorsement, pointing out that more than
130,000 Rendezvous vehicles were sold in 2002 and 2003. "That exceeded our
forecasts," he was quoted as saying, "It has to be in recognition of Tiger."
In February 2004, Buick renewed Woods' endorsement contract for another five
years, in a deal reportedly worth $40 million.[151]

Woods collaborated closely with [TAG Heuer](/wiki/TAG_Heuer "TAG Heuer") to
develop the world's first professional golf watch, which was released in April
2005.[155] The lightweight, [titanium](/wiki/Titanium "Titanium")-construction
watch, designed to be worn while playing the game, incorporates numerous
innovative design features to accommodate golf play. It is capable of
absorbing up to 5,000 [Gs](/wiki/G-force "G-force") of shock, far in excess of
the forces generated by a normal golf swing.[155] In 2006, the TAG Heuer
_Professional Golf Watch_ won the prestigious _[iF product design
award](/wiki/IF_product_design_award "IF product design award")_ in the
Leisure/Lifestyle category.[156]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Woods_photo_shoot.jpg/170px-
Woods_photo_shoot.jpg)](/wiki/File:Woods_photo_shoot.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Woods_photo_shoot.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods preparing for a photo shoot in 2006

Woods also endorsed the [Tiger Woods PGA Tour](/wiki/Tiger_Woods_PGA_Tour
"Tiger Woods PGA Tour") series of video games; he has done so since 1999.[157]
In 2006, he signed a six-year contract with [Electronic
Arts](/wiki/Electronic_Arts "Electronic Arts"), the series' publisher.[158]

In February 2007, Woods, [Roger Federer](/wiki/Roger_Federer "Roger Federer")
and [Thierry Henry](/wiki/Thierry_Henry "Thierry Henry") became ambassadors
for the "[Gillette](/wiki/Global_Gillette "Global Gillette") Champions"
marketing campaign. Gillette did not disclose financial terms, though an
expert estimated the deal could total between $10 million and $20
million.[159]

In October 2007, [Gatorade](/wiki/Gatorade "Gatorade") announced that Woods
would have his own brand of sports drink starting in March 2008. "Gatorade
Tiger" was his first U.S. deal with a beverage company and his first licensing
agreement. Although no figures were officially disclosed, _Golfweek_ magazine
reported that it was for five years and could pay him as much as $100
million.[160] The company decided in early fall 2009 to discontinue the drink
due to weak sales.[161]

In October 2012, it was announced that Woods had signed an exclusive
endorsement deal with Fuse Science, Inc, a [sports
nutrition](/wiki/Sports_nutrition "Sports nutrition") firm.[162]

In 1997, Woods and golfer [Arnold Palmer](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer "Arnold Palmer")
initiated a case against Bruce Matthews (the owner of Gotta Have It Golf,
Inc.) and others in the effort to stop the unauthorized sale of their images
and alleged signatures in the memorabilia market. Matthews and associated
parties counterclaimed that Woods and his company, ETW Corporation, committed
several acts including breach of contract, breach of implied duty of good
faith, and violations of Florida's Deceptive and Unfair Trade Practices
Act.[163] Palmer also was named in the counter-suit, accused of violating the
same licensing agreement in conjunction with his company Arnold Palmer
Enterprises.

On March 12, 2014, a Florida jury ruled in favor of Gotta Have It on its
breach of contract and other related claims, rejected ETW's counterclaims, and
awarded Gotta Have It $668,346 in damages.[164][165] The award may end up
exceeding $1 million once interest has been factored in, though the ruling may
be appealed.

In August 2016, Woods announced that he would be seeking a new golf equipment
partner[166] after the news of Nike's exit from the equipment industry.[167]
It was announced on January 25, 2017, that he would be signing a new club deal
with [TaylorMade](/wiki/TaylorMade-Adidas "TaylorMade-Adidas").[168] He added
the 2016 M2 driver along with the 2017 M1 fairway woods, with irons to be
custom made at a later date. He also added his [Scotty
Cameron](/wiki/Scotty_Cameron "Scotty Cameron") Newport 2 GSS, a club he used
to win 13 of his 14 majors.[169] Also, in late 2016, he would add [Monster
Energy](/wiki/Monster_Energy "Monster Energy") as his primary bag sponsor,
replacing MusclePharm.[170]

### Accumulated wealth

According to _Golf Digest_ , Woods made $769,440,709 from 1996 to 2007,[171]
and the magazine predicted that Woods would pass one billion dollars in
earnings by 2010.[172] In 2009, _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ confirmed
that Woods was indeed the world's first athlete to earn over a billion dollars
in his career, after accounting for the $10 million bonus Woods received for
the [FedEx Cup](/wiki/FedEx_Cup "FedEx Cup") title.[173][174] The same year,
Forbes estimated his net worth to be $600 million, making him the second
richest [person of color](/wiki/Person_of_color "Person of color") in the
United States, behind only [Oprah Winfrey](/wiki/Oprah_Winfrey "Oprah
Winfrey").[175] In 2015, Woods ranked ninth in [Forbes' list of world's
highest-paid athletes](/wiki/Forbes%27_list_of_world%27s_highest-paid_athletes
"Forbes' list of world's highest-paid athletes"), being the top among Asian
Americans or the fourth among African Americans.[176] Woods is currently
considered to be the highest-paid golfer.[177]

### Tiger-proofing

Early in Woods' career, a small number of golf experts expressed concern about
his impact on the competitiveness of the game and the public appeal of
professional golf. Sportswriter Bill Lyon of [Knight
Ridder](/wiki/Knight_Ridder "Knight Ridder") asked in a column, "Isn't Tiger
Woods actually bad for golf?" (though Lyon ultimately concluded that he was
not).[178] At first, some pundits feared that Woods would drive the spirit of
competition out of the game of golf by making existing courses obsolete and
relegating opponents to simply competing for second place each week.

A related effect was measured by [University of
California](/wiki/University_of_California,_Berkeley "University of
California, Berkeley") economist Jennifer Brown, who found that other golfers
scored higher when competing against Woods than when he was not in the
tournament. The scores of highly skilled (exempt) golfers are nearly one
stroke higher when playing against Woods. This effect was larger when he was
on winning streaks and disappeared during his well-publicized slump in
2003–04. Brown explains the results by noting that competitors of similar
skill can hope to win by increasing their level of effort, but that, when
facing a "superstar" competitor, extra exertion does not significantly raise
one's level of winning while increasing risk of injury or exhaustion, leading
to reduced effort.[179]

Many courses in the PGA Tour rotation (including major championship sites like
[Augusta National](/wiki/Augusta_National_Golf_Club "Augusta National Golf
Club")) have added yardage to their tees in an effort to reduce the advantage
of long hitters like Woods, a strategy that became known as "Tiger-Proofing".
Woods said he welcomed the change, in that adding yardage to courses did not
affect his ability to win.[180]

## Career achievements

Main article: [List of career achievements by Tiger
Woods](/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Tiger_Woods "List of career
achievements by Tiger Woods")

Woods has won 80 official [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA Tour") events,
including 14 [majors](/wiki/Men%27s_major_golf_championships "Men's major golf
championships"). He is 14–1 when going into the final round of a major with at
least a share of the lead. Multiple golf experts have heralded Woods as "the
greatest closer in history".[181][182][183] He owns the lowest career scoring
average and the most career earnings of any player in PGA Tour history.

Woods' victory at the [2013 Players
Championship](/wiki/2013_Players_Championship "2013 Players Championship")
also marked a win in his 300th [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA Tour")
start.[184] He also won golf tournaments in his [100th](/wiki/WGC-
Bridgestone_Invitational#Winners "WGC-Bridgestone Invitational") (in 2000) and
[200th](/wiki/Farmers_Insurance_Open#Winners "Farmers Insurance Open") (in
2006) tour starts.[185][186]

Woods has spent the most consecutive and cumulative weeks atop the world
rankings. He is one of five players (along with [Gene
Sarazen](/wiki/Gene_Sarazen "Gene Sarazen"), [Ben Hogan](/wiki/Ben_Hogan "Ben
Hogan"), [Gary Player](/wiki/Gary_Player "Gary Player"), and [Jack
Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus")) to have won all four
professional major championships in his career, known as the Career Grand
Slam, and was the youngest to do so.[187] Woods is the only player to have won
all four professional major championships in a row, accomplishing the feat in
the 2000–2001 seasons.

  * **[PGA Tour wins (80)](/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Tiger_Woods#PGA_Tour_wins_\(80\) "List of career achievements by Tiger Woods")**
  * **[European Tour wins (40)](/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Tiger_Woods#European_Tour_wins_\(40\) "List of career achievements by Tiger Woods")**
  * **[Japan Golf Tour wins (2)](/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Tiger_Woods#Japan_Golf_Tour_wins_\(2\) "List of career achievements by Tiger Woods")**
  * **[Asian Tour wins (1)](/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Tiger_Woods#Asian_Tour_wins_\(1\) "List of career achievements by Tiger Woods")**
  * **[PGA Tour of Australasia wins (1)](/wiki/List_of_career_achievements_by_Tiger_Woods#PGA_Tour_of_Australasia_wins_\(1\) "List of career achievements by Tiger Woods")**

### _Guinness Book of Records_

Woods claimed 17 _[Guinness World Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records
"Guinness World Records")_ , within golf and 3 other records related to his
appearance in the video game. After [Usain Bolt](/wiki/Usain_Bolt "Usain
Bolt") and [Michael Phelps](/wiki/Michael_Phelps "Michael Phelps"), he holds
the third highest number of Guinness World Records claimed by a sportsman
within one discipline.[189]

  1. Most consecutive US Amateur golf titles
  2. Most US PGA Tour tournament wins in the modern era
  3. Lowest score under par in the Open golf championships
  4. Most awards for Professional Golfers' Association Tour Player of the Year
  5. Youngest winner of the golf US Masters
  6. Highest career earnings on the US Professional Golfers' Association Tour
  7. Largest margin of victory in the golf US Masters
  8. Largest margin of victory in a golf major championships
  9. Most wins of the PGA Player of the Year award
  10. Most consecutive golf Major tournaments won
  11. Highest annual earnings for a golfer
  12. Longest golf drive on the PGA Tour
  13. Lowest total score (72 holes) at the golf US Masters
  14. Longest drive in Tiger Woods PGA Tour 06
  15. Golf, World Cup - Lowest individual score
  16. Lowest total score (first 54 holes) in the golf US Masters
  17. Highest annual earnings for an athlete (ever)

## Playing style

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/TigerWoods2004RyderCup3.jpg/170px-
TigerWoods2004RyderCup3.jpg)](/wiki/File:TigerWoods2004RyderCup3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:TigerWoods2004RyderCup3.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods practicing before [2004 Ryder Cup](/wiki/2004_Ryder_Cup "2004 Ryder
Cup") at [Oakland Hills Country Club](/wiki/Oakland_Hills_Country_Club
"Oakland Hills Country Club") in [Bloomfield
Township](/wiki/Bloomfield_Township,_Oakland_County,_Michigan "Bloomfield
Township, Oakland County, Michigan"), Michigan

When Woods first joined the [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA Tour") in 1996, his
long drives had a large impact on the world of golf.[190][191] However, when
he did not upgrade his equipment in the following years (insisting upon the
use of True Temper Dynamic Gold steel-shafted clubs and smaller steel
clubheads that promoted accuracy over distance),[192] many opponents caught up
to him. Phil Mickelson even made a joke in 2003 about Woods using "inferior
equipment", which did not sit well with [Nike](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc."),
[Titleist](/wiki/Titleist "Titleist") or Woods.[193][194] During 2004, Woods
finally upgraded his driver technology to a larger clubhead and
[graphite](/wiki/Graphite "Graphite") shaft, which, coupled with his clubhead
speed, made him one of the Tour's lengthiest players off the
[tee](/wiki/Golf_tee "Golf tee") once again.

Despite his power advantage, Woods has always focused on developing an
excellent all-around game. Although in recent
years[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] he has typically been near
the bottom of the Tour rankings in driving accuracy, his iron play is
generally accurate, his recovery and bunker play is very strong, and his
putting (especially under pressure) is possibly his greatest asset. He is
largely responsible for a shift to higher standards of athleticism amongst
professional golfers, and is known for utilizing more hours of practice than
most.[195][196][197]

From mid-1993 (while he was still an amateur) until 2004, Woods worked almost
exclusively with leading swing coach [Butch Harmon](/wiki/Butch_Harmon "Butch
Harmon"). From mid-1997, Harmon and Woods fashioned a major redevelopment of
Woods' full swing, achieving greater consistency, better distance control, and
better [kinesiology](/wiki/Kinesiology "Kinesiology"). The changes began to
pay off in 1999.[198] From March 2004 to 2010, Woods was coached by [Hank
Haney](/wiki/Hank_Haney "Hank Haney"), who worked on flattening his swing
plane. Woods continued to win tournaments with Haney, but his driving accuracy
dropped significantly. Haney resigned in May 2010 and was replaced by [Sean
Foley](/wiki/Sean_Foley_\(golf_instructor\) "Sean Foley \(golf
instructor\)").[199]

[Fluff Cowan](/wiki/Mike_Cowan "Mike Cowan") served as Woods'
[caddie](/wiki/Caddie "Caddie") from the start of his professional career
until Woods dismissed him in March 1999.[200] He was replaced by [Steve
Williams](/wiki/Steve_Williams_\(caddy\) "Steve Williams \(caddy\)"), who
became a close friend of Woods and is often credited with helping him with key
shots and putts.[201] In June 2011, Woods dismissed Williams and replaced him
with friend Bryon Bell on an interim basis. Joe LaCava, a former caddie of
both [Fred Couples](/wiki/Fred_Couples "Fred Couples") and [Dustin
Johnson](/wiki/Dustin_Johnson "Dustin Johnson"), was hired by Woods shortly
after[202] and has remained Woods' caddie since then, but he has seen limited
work.

## Other ventures

### Tiger Woods Foundation

The [Tiger Woods Foundation](/wiki/Tiger_Woods_Foundation "Tiger Woods
Foundation") was established in 1996 by Woods and his father Earl, with the
primary goal of promoting golf among inner-city children.[208][209] The
foundation has conducted junior golf clinics across the country, and sponsors
the Tiger Woods Foundation National Junior Golf Team in the Junior World Golf
Championships.[210][211] As of December 2010, TWF employed approximately 55
people.[212][213]

The foundation operates the [Tiger Woods Learning
Center](/wiki/Tiger_Woods_Learning_Center "Tiger Woods Learning Center"), a
$50 million, 35,000-square-foot (3,250 m²) facility in [Anaheim,
California](/wiki/Anaheim,_California "Anaheim, California"), providing
college-access programs for underserved youth.[210][212][214] The TWLC opened
in 2006 and features seven classrooms, extensive multi-media facilities and an
outdoor golf teaching area.[210] The center has since expanded to four
additional campuses: two in [Washington, D.C.](/wiki/Washington,_D.C.
"Washington, D.C."); one in [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia");
and one in [Stuart, Florida](/wiki/Stuart,_Florida "Stuart, Florida").[214]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Tiger_Woods_speaks_at_We_Are_One.JPG/220px-
Tiger_Woods_speaks_at_We_Are_One.JPG)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_speaks_at_We_Are_One.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_speaks_at_We_Are_One.JPG "Enlarge")

Woods giving a speech at [We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration at the
Lincoln
Memorial](/wiki/We_Are_One:_The_Obama_Inaugural_Celebration_at_the_Lincoln_Memorial
"We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln Memorial")
(January 2009)

The foundation benefits from the annual [Chevron World
Challenge](/wiki/Chevron_World_Challenge "Chevron World Challenge") and [AT&T
National](/wiki/AT%26T_National "AT&T National") golf tournaments hosted by
Woods.[212] In October 2011, the foundation hosted the first Tiger Woods
Invitational at Pebble Beach.[215] Other annual fundraisers have included the
concert events Block Party, last held in 2009 in Anaheim, and Tiger Jam, last
held in 2011 in [Las Vegas](/wiki/Las_Vegas_Valley "Las Vegas Valley") after a
one-year hiatus.[212][216][217][218]

### Tiger Woods Design

In November 2006, Woods announced his intention to begin designing golf
courses around the world through a new company, [Tiger Woods
Design](/wiki/Tiger_Woods_Design "Tiger Woods Design").[219] A month later, he
announced that the company's first course would be in [Dubai](/wiki/Dubai
"Dubai") as part of a 25.3 million-square-foot development, [The Tiger Woods
Dubai](/wiki/The_Tiger_Woods_Dubai "The Tiger Woods Dubai").[220] The Al
Ruwaya Golf Course was initially expected to finish construction in 2009.[220]
As of February 2010, only seven holes had been completed; in April 2011, _The
New York Times_ reported that the project had been shelved
permanently.[221][222] In 2013, the partnership between Tiger Woods Design and
Dubai Holding was dissolved.[223]

Tiger Woods Design has taken on two other courses, neither of which has
materialized. In August 2007, Woods announced The Cliffs at High Carolina, a
private course in the [Blue Ridge Mountains](/wiki/Blue_Ridge_Mountains "Blue
Ridge Mountains") near [Asheville, North
Carolina](/wiki/Asheville,_North_Carolina "Asheville, North Carolina").[224]
After a groundbreaking in November 2008, the project suffered cash flow
problems and suspended construction.[222] A third course, in [Punta
Brava](/wiki/Punta_Brava_Golf_Club "Punta Brava Golf Club"),
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"), was announced in October 2008, but incurred
delays due to issues with permits and an [environmental impact
study](/wiki/Environmental_impact_study "Environmental impact
study").[222][225] Construction on the Punta Brava course has not yet
begun.[222]

These projects have encountered problems that have been attributed to factors
that include overly optimistic estimates of their value, declines throughout
the global economy (particularly the [U.S. crash in home
prices](/wiki/United_States_housing_bubble "United States housing bubble")),
and the decreased appeal and marketability of Woods following his 2009
infidelity scandal.[222]

### Writings

Woods wrote a golf instruction column for _[Golf Digest](/wiki/Golf_Digest
"Golf Digest")_ magazine from 1997 to February 2011.[226] In 2001 he wrote a
best-selling golf instruction book, _How I Play Golf_ , which had the largest
print run of any golf book for its first edition, 1.5 million copies.[227] In
March 2017, he published a memoir, _The 1997 Masters: My Story_ , co-authored
by [Lorne Rubenstein](/wiki/Lorne_Rubenstein "Lorne Rubenstein"), which
focuses on his first Masters win.[228]

## Personal life

### Marriage and children

In November 2003, Woods became engaged to [Elin
Nordegren](/wiki/Elin_Nordegren "Elin Nordegren"), a Swedish former model and
daughter of former minister of migration [Barbro
Holmberg](/wiki/Barbro_Holmberg "Barbro Holmberg") and radio journalist
[Thomas Nordegren](/wiki/Thomas_Nordegren "Thomas Nordegren").[229] They were
introduced during The Open Championship in 2001 by Swedish golfer [Jesper
Parnevik](/wiki/Jesper_Parnevik "Jesper Parnevik"), who had employed her as an
[au pair](/wiki/Au_pair "Au pair"). They married on October 5, 2004, at the
[Sandy Lane resort](/wiki/Sandy_Lane_\(resort\) "Sandy Lane \(resort\)") in
[Barbados](/wiki/Barbados "Barbados"), and lived at
[Isleworth](/wiki/Isleworth,_Windermere,_Florida "Isleworth, Windermere,
Florida"), a community in [Windermere](/wiki/Windermere,_Florida "Windermere,
Florida"), a suburb of [Orlando, Florida](/wiki/Orlando,_Florida "Orlando,
Florida").[230][231] In 2006, they purchased a $39-million estate in [Jupiter
Island, Florida](/wiki/Jupiter_Island,_Florida "Jupiter Island, Florida"), and
began constructing a 10,000-square-foot home; Woods moved there in 2010
following the couple's divorce.[5][231]

Woods and Nordegren's first child was a girl born in 2007, whom they named Sam
Alexis Woods. Woods chose the name because his own father had always called
him Sam.[232] Their son, Charlie Axel Woods, was born in 2009.[233]

### Infidelity scandal and fallout

In November 2009, the _[National Enquirer](/wiki/National_Enquirer "National
Enquirer")_ published a story claiming that Woods had had an [extramarital
affair](/wiki/Extramarital_sex "Extramarital sex") with New York City
nightclub manager [Rachel Uchitel](/wiki/Rachel_Uchitel "Rachel Uchitel"), who
denied the claim.[234][235] Two days later, around 2:30 a.m. on November 27,
Woods was driving from his Florida mansion in his [Cadillac
Escalade](/wiki/Cadillac_Escalade "Cadillac Escalade") SUV when he collided
with a fire hydrant, a tree, and several hedges near his home.[236] He was
treated for minor facial lacerations and received a ticket for careless
driving.[236][237] Following intense media speculation about the cause of the
accident, Woods released a statement on his website and took sole
responsibility for the accident, calling it a "private matter" and crediting
his wife for helping him from the car.[238][239] On November 30, Woods
announced that he would not be appearing at his own charity golf tournament,
the [Chevron World Challenge](/wiki/Chevron_World_Challenge "Chevron World
Challenge"), nor any other tournaments in 2009, due to his injuries.[240]

On December 2, following _[Us Weekly](/wiki/Us_Weekly "Us Weekly")_ 's
previous day reporting of a purported mistress and subsequent release of a
voicemail message allegedly left by Woods for the woman,[241] Woods released a
further statement. He admitted "transgressions" and apologized to "all of
those who have supported [him] over the years", while reiterating his and his
family's right to privacy.[235][242] Over the next few days, more than a dozen
women claimed in various media outlets to have had affairs with Woods.[11] On
December 11, he released a third statement admitting to infidelity and
apologizing again, as well as announcing that he would be taking "an
indefinite break from professional golf."[11]

In the days and months following Woods's admission of multiple infidelities,
several companies re-evaluated their relationships with him.
[Accenture](/wiki/Accenture "Accenture"), [AT&T](/wiki/AT%26T_Inc. "AT&T
Inc."), [Gatorade](/wiki/Gatorade "Gatorade") and [General
Motors](/wiki/General_Motors "General Motors") completely ended their
sponsorship deals, while [Gillette](/wiki/Gillette_\(brand\) "Gillette
\(brand\)") suspended advertising featuring Woods.[98][243][244] [TAG
Heuer](/wiki/TAG_Heuer "TAG Heuer") dropped Woods from advertising in December
2009 and officially ended their deal when his contract expired in August
2011.[98] _[Golf Digest](/wiki/Golf_Digest "Golf Digest")_ suspended Woods's
monthly column beginning with the February 2010 issue.[245] In contrast,
[Nike](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc.") continued to support Woods, as did
[Electronic Arts](/wiki/Electronic_Arts "Electronic Arts"), which was working
with Woods on the game _[Tiger Woods PGA Tour
Online](/wiki/Tiger_Woods_PGA_Tour_Online "Tiger Woods PGA Tour
Online")_.[246] A December 2009 study estimated the shareholder loss caused by
Woods's affairs to be between $5 billion and $12 billion.[247]

On February 19, 2010, Woods gave a televised statement in which he said he had
undertaken a 45-day therapy program beginning at the end of December. He again
apologized for his actions. "I thought I could get away with whatever I wanted
to," he said. "I felt that I had worked hard my entire life and deserved to
enjoy all the temptations around me. I felt I was entitled. Thanks to money
and fame, I didn't have to go far to find them. I was wrong. I was foolish."
He said he did not know yet when he would be returning to golf.[97][248] He
announced a few weeks later on March 16 that he would play in the [2010
Masters Tournament](/wiki/2010_Masters_Tournament "2010 Masters Tournament")
on April 8.[249]

After seven years of marriage, Woods and his wife Elin divorced on August 23,
2010.[250]

### 2017 arrest

On May 29, 2017, Woods was arrested near his [Jupiter Island,
Florida](/wiki/Jupiter_Island,_Florida "Jupiter Island, Florida"), home by the
Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office at about 3:00 a.m. EDT for driving under
the influence of alcohol or drugs. He was asleep in his car, which was
stationary in a traffic lane with its engine running. He later stated that he
was taking prescription drugs and did not realize how they might interact
together.[251][252][253] On July 3, 2017, Woods tweeted that he had completed
an out-of-state intensive program to tackle an unspecified issue.[254] On
August 9, 2017, Woods, who skipped his arraignment,[255] entered a not guilty
plea through his attorney Douglas Duncan and agreed to take part in a first-
time DUI offender program and attend another arraignment on October 25.[256]

At a hearing on October 27, 2017, Woods pleaded guilty to reckless driving. He
received a year of probation, was fined $250, and ordered to undergo 50 hours
of [community service](/wiki/Community_service "Community service") along with
regular drug tests. He was not allowed to drink alcohol during the probation,
and if he violates the probation he will be sentenced to 90 days in jail with
an additional $500 fine.[257]

### Other pursuits

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5c/Barack_Obama_meets_Tiger_Woods_4-20-09.jpg/220px-
Barack_Obama_meets_Tiger_Woods_4-20-09.jpg)](/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_meets_Tiger_Woods_4-20-09.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_meets_Tiger_Woods_4-20-09.jpg "Enlarge")

United States President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") and
Woods meet in the [Oval Office](/wiki/Oval_Office "Oval Office"), April 2009

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Tiger_Woods_at_Naval_Base_Coronado_2006-05-31.jpg/220px-
Tiger_Woods_at_Naval_Base_Coronado_2006-05-31.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_at_Naval_Base_Coronado_2006-05-31.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tiger_Woods_at_Naval_Base_Coronado_2006-05-31.jpg "Enlarge")

Woods shoots a handgun at a shooting range outside San Diego.

Woods was raised as a [Buddhist](/wiki/Buddhism "Buddhism"), and he actively
practiced his faith from childhood until well into his adult, professional
golf career.[258] In a 2000 article, Woods was quoted as saying that he
"believes in Buddhism... not every aspect, but most of it."[259] He has
attributed his deviations and infidelity to his losing track of Buddhism. He
said, "Buddhism teaches me to stop following every impulse and to learn
restraint. Obviously I lost track of what I was taught."[260]

Woods is registered as an [independent](/wiki/Independent_\(voter\)
"Independent \(voter\)") voter.[261] In January 2009, Woods delivered a speech
commemorating the military at the [We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration
at the Lincoln
Memorial](/wiki/We_Are_One:_The_Obama_Inaugural_Celebration_at_the_Lincoln_Memorial
"We Are One: The Obama Inaugural Celebration at the Lincoln
Memorial").[262][263] In April 2009, Woods visited the [White
House](/wiki/White_House "White House") while promoting the golf tournament he
hosts, the [AT&T National](/wiki/AT%26T_National "AT&T National").[264] In
December 2016 and again in November 2017, Woods played golf with President
[Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") at the [Trump International
Golf Club](/wiki/Trump_International_Golf_Club_\(West_Palm_Beach\) "Trump
International Golf Club \(West Palm Beach\)") in [West Palm
Beach](/wiki/West_Palm_Beach "West Palm Beach").[265]

Woods underwent [laser eye surgery](/wiki/Refractive_surgery "Refractive
surgery") in 1999. Before this surgery, he was severely myopic, his eyesight
having a rating of 11 [diopters](/wiki/Dioptre "Dioptre"). The surgery was
successful (it has meant that he does not need to wear glasses or use contact
lenses)[266], as he immediately started winning tour events. He received money
from TLC Laser Eye Centers to endorse them.[267] In 2007, he had further laser
eye surgery when his vision began to deteriorate again.[268]

On March 18, 2013, Woods announced that he and Olympic gold medal skier
[Lindsey Vonn](/wiki/Lindsey_Vonn "Lindsey Vonn") were dating.[269] They split
up in May 2015.[270]
